title: chinas top medic coronavirus wuhan
story: CHINAS top medic has blasted irresponsible claims coronavirus originated in the city of Wuhan, once the diseases epicentre.Coronavirus expert Dr Zhong Nanshan leads a top team of doctors spearheading Chinas battle against COVID-.Hubei Province, whose capital city is Wuhan, was coronavirus ground zero when the epidemic exploded in January, with , of the worlds , deaths taking place there.But today it registered no new cases for the first time since the deadly outbreak began at the end of December.Donald Trump has sparked anger by branding coronavirus Chinese flu and accused Beijing of a cover-up. But Dr Zhang insists its wrong to pin the blame on Wuhan, a city of  million people.Dr Zhong, , said: The epidemic of the novel coronavirus pneumonia indeed took place in China, in Wuhan… but it does not mean its source is in Wuhan.It is a scientic problem. I think it is irresponsible to conclude lightly before [the matter] is claried.A Beijing spokesman tweeted last week that the deadly virus may have have been brought to Wuhan by the US military.But experts believe the virus source was wild animals sold at a seafood market in Wuhan.Donald Trump has labelled coronavirus Chinese Flu during his daily press conferences and in furious Twitter broadsides.But the US President has denied the phrase is racist and slammed China as the world is paying a big price for their cover-up.He told reporters this week: It comes from China. It’s not racist at all.I want to be accurate.China tried to say at one point, maybe they have stopped now, that it was caused by American soldiers.That can’t happen. That’s not going to happen.Not as long as I’m President.China and Wuhan celebrated today after no new cases were reported for the first time since the killer bug swept across the country in late December.Residents who had been in quarantine for weeks were filmed going outside as travel restrictions were relaxed.But there are strict -day quarantine regulations in place for anyone arriving into China, with fears people from overseas could bring the virus with them.It came on the day the number of coronavirus deaths in Italy overtook Chinas toll.In just one day,  died from the virus in Italy, pushing the number of fatalities there to ,.Italy has an older population than Chinas and medical experts say the new virus is killing people over  at a much higher rate than other age groups.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: defeat coronavirus nation play part
story: We all need rapidly to get a grip.The Government’s advice, backed by its scientists, has been clear enough: Avoid pubs and restaurants, where the virus can so easily spread.Stop the brainless panic-buying and hoarding which strips shelves of essentials ALL of us need — especially OAPs, exhausted NHS workers and the low-paid.Yet some pubs remain packed, notably in London where two-thirds of the latest deaths occurred.Some young people think a pint is worth the risk.Old folk reckon Britain saw off the Nazis, so they won’t be cowed by a microscopic bug.We can understand it . . . but both attitudes are delusional and irresponsible.It won’t just be their problemthey catch Covid-.They could infect an old or sick person, who dies.And the NHS will have to cope with all of it.People must stay at home.And though The Sun has always been a friend to our pubs, Boris Johnson must ignore his liberal instincts and shut themneed be.Supermarkets, meanwhile, insist the food supply is perfectly adequate IF people shop sensibly and considerately.But queues snake around the block at dawn.Selfish shoppers buy enough loo roll, pasta and medicine for months.It is insane, unnecessary and must stop. It causes hardship. It makes others panic.“Our nation’s history has been forged by people coming together to work as one, concentrating our combined efforts with a focus on the common goal,” says the Queen.She is absolutely right.Most ARE taking seriously their safety and other people’s. Too many are not.Do your bit. Remain home wherever possible.Only buy supplies you need.Britain has prevailed before by uniting in a common cause. It is vital we do it now.MORE soothing words from Boris for ­panic-stricken businesses — but where is the money to pay workers’ wages Yet another day passes, with thousands more jobs lost.Firms WILL stand by staffthey can afford to, PM.But your Chancellor must write cheques today or the weekend will be carnage.THE Windrush generation were shamefully treated by the Home Office.They were wrongly deported to the Caribbean like illegal migrants when they were perfectly entitled to be here.To learn that wasn’t just incompetence but “institutional ignorance” over race is even more shocking.But when Priti Patel, a British-Asian Home Secretary, cracked the whip, the Left backed the pen-pushers.What strange loyalties.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: google doodle hand washing ignaz semmelweis
story: The timely animation shows a range of dferent techniques to help make sure youre washing your hands effectively - as the world faces the spread of deadly bug coronavirus.Todays Google Doodle, Semmelweis was a physician and scientist born in Buda, the ancient capital of the Kingdom of Hungary - now the western part of Budapest.He was born July ,  and passed away in a mental hospital in August , .The physician is famous for introducing hand disinfection standards in obstetrical care.Hes even been described as the father of infection control, although it was only after his heath that his beliefs around cleanliness were recognised as germ theory of disease was widely accepted.According to the World Health Organisation, thorough hand-washing is a key way of preventing the spread of coronavirus.WHO advise frequent hand-washing with soap and water or using an alcohol-based hand sanitiser.On March , , Semmelweis emphasised the importance of having clean hands when he became chief resident in the maternity clinic of the Vienna General Hospital.He demanded that all physicians disinfect their hands with a solution made from chlorinated lime.In , the search engine founders Larry and Sergey drew a stick figure behind the second o of Google as a message to that they were out of office at the Burning Man festival and with that, Google Doodles were born.The company decided that they should decorate the logo to mark cultural moments and it soon became clear that users really enjoyed the change to the Google homepage.In that same year, a turkey was added to Thanksgiving and two pumpkins appeared as the os for Halloween the following year.Now, there is a full team of doodlers, illustrators, graphic designers, animators and classically trained artists who help create what you see on those days.Among the Doodles published in past months were designs commemorating German scientist Robert Koch, Jan Ingenhousz  and the th anniversary of kids coding languages being introduced.And the search giant celebrated the  Autumn Equinox , which marked the official ending of summer and the coming of autumn.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fit and healthy woman coronavirus
story: A FIT and healthy mum who caught coronavirus has warned of its dangers in a chilling video from her hospital bed.Tara Jane Langston, , filmed herself in an intensive care unitin Hillingdon Hospital, West London begging people not to take any chances with catching the killer bug.The mum-of-two was rushed to hospital last Friday after being diagnosed with COVID-, which she says feels like having glass in your lungs.In the horrying video, which she sent as a warning to pals, gym-going Ms Langston is seen choking and struggling to breathe.Speaking to the camera as she gasps for air, Ms Langston said: If anyone is thinking of taking any chances, just take a look at me.Im in the intensive care unit. I cant breathe without this. Theyve had to sew that into my artery. Ive got a cannula, another cannula and a catheter.Im actually ten times better right now than what I was before. Ive lost count of the days.If anyone still smokes, put the cigarettes down, because Im telling you now, you need your f***ing lungs.And please none of you take any chances. Becauseit gets really bad then you are going to end up here.The shocking footage comes as the UKs death toll soared to  on Thursday, a jump of  in just  hours.Already, more than , people here have caught the disease which has stunned the world and left scientists locked in a desperate race to find a vaccine.Ms Langston told MailOnline: It’s like having glass in your lungs, it’s hard to explain, but every breath is a battle.It’s absolutely horrible and I wouldn’t want to go through anything like this ever again. I’d been ill for about five days before I was taken to hospital in an ambulance.I’d originally been diagnosed with a chest infection and given antibiotics and advised to take ibuprofen and paracetamol.I was taking about eight ibuprofen a day and they now think that that exacerbated the problem.When I was taken into intensive care they originally planned to sedate me and keep me in intubation because my body had gone through it all for the best part of a week and I was shattered.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Fortunately I was kept awake but needed six litres of oxygen. Now that I’m improving I’m on one litre.Ms Langston was diagnosed with the chest infection last week.She was seen by doctors  days ago after going on holiday to Krakow in Poland with husband Richard and their two daughters.At Hillingdon Hospital, she was diagnosed with a chest infection and given antibiotics before going home in a cab.But she was taken back to the hospital in an ambulance later in the week and diagnosed with pneumonia.She was confirmed as having tested positive for coronavirus on Sunday.Ms Langston added: There were two other patients with me in the ICU, both of who were being intubated.One was quite a large man who I’d say was about late s or early s and the other was a lady roughly the same age.So these were not elderly people.That was my reasoning behind doing that video was to warn that younger people are susceptible too.It’s quite surreal being in the ICU, the nurses are covered head to toe but they are literally working non-stop and have been brilliant.They are actually running out of face masks. One nurse came into my room the other day with a sort of plastic sheeting covering her face, it looked like the sort of clear plastic wrapper flowers come in.And she admitted she is worriedthe virus starts getting worse the hospital will be swamped with coronavirus patients.She begged people to self-isolate and insisted its the only way.Ms Langston added: I can understand their mind-set because I had that attitude before of it’s a load of nonsense, it’s just being all hyped up before I got this– I wasn’t one to buy into all the hysteria.But then I got the coronavirus and I never again want to experience anything like it because it was a deeply unpleasant experience.That’s why I filmed myself in the ICU and sent it to my work mates because they were supposed to be all meeting up for a training event and I wanted to tell them not to go as it wasn’t worth the risk.They’d be better off staying at home self-isolating.Whatever restrictions the government has now been put in place should have been done two weeks ago I believe.My story should be a warning to others – you need to take this seriously.Her husband Richard fears she could have caught the virus at the gym.He said: She’s out of intensive care now and is making good progress. We just want her back at home.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: coronavirus government phone data track people lockdowns
story: THE government could use location data from smartphones to see whether people are following social distancing rules, according to reports.Both O and BT, which owns one of the UKs largest phone networks EE, are in talks with the government over how to use mobile data to monitor the publics response to policies aimed at stopping the spread of the coronavirus.Both companies could provide the government with anonymous maps of data, allowing them to see whether people were obeying government advice to stay away from pubs and restaurants.This could aid the government in shaping future policy and evaluating how effective its social distancing and transport restrictions are.But both companies insist this will not allow them to track iniduals.Similar measures have already been carried out much further in South Korea, which has used apps to monitor the spread of the disease.Israel also recently passed an emergency law which allows the government to track the spread of the virus using data from mobile phones.A BT spokeswoman said that they wished to assist with the national public health effort in the UK.She said: We are talking with the Government about a number of areas in which we may be able to assist with the national public health effort.In relation to the use of mobile data, we are still actively exploring possibilities. As always, we are mindful of the privacy of our customers, while making sure we do everything that might help the medical authorities in the fight against coronavirus.A statement from O stressed that it would definitely not share any data that might help identy iniduals.The statement read: We are fully engaged in helping in the fight against COVID-. Besides zero rating access to NHS and other support websites, we were asked along with other mobile operators to support those who are working tirelessly to map and control the spread of coronavirus in the UK. Using our mobile technology, we have the potential to build models that help to predict broadly how the virus might move. This would in no way be able to identy or map iniduals, and operates within strict privacy guidelines.It comes after Boris Johnson said the bug can be “sent packing”the public follow the strict new rules around social distancing and travel set out by the government.He urged the nation: Don’t go to the pub, work from home and wash your hands.The death toll in the UK has risen to , with , cases recorded.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. preparation it will still be possible to eat well.YouTube and Instagram star Suzanne Mulholland — aka The Batch Lady — believes the key to coping with any enforced confinement is getting organised now and NOT panic-buying.The mum of two, who lives on the Scottish Borders with her husband Peter, , and children Jake, , and -year-old Zara, has devised a system where your meal-time preparation just means grabbing something from the freezer.Suzanne, , says: “There is no point in panic-buying more than you need, especiallythese goods are perishable and won’t last.It’s much better to plan ahead wisely, and get organised in advance.“I’ve been batch cooking for more than ten years and started when my children were small.“I realised I was spending too long cooking meals, and knew there must be a more effective way.I’ve developed a system where I make modern batch-cooked meals that can all be made in advance and stored in the freezer.“I’m all about efficiency and my background is in business title: china asian countries second wave infections
story: China, South Korea, Japan and Singapore were preparing to ease restrictions as numbers of new cases slowed.But they were rowing back as new pockets of infection, involving sufferers ing from abroad, flared up.China has reportedly had no new domestic cases but  new infections among those who recently ed home.The national death toll in the country stands at , - according to the Communist regime.Chinese leaders ordered massive lockdowns which left millions confined to their homes for up to six weeks in a state of mass quarantine.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Professor David Heymann, of the London School of Hygiene  Tropical Medicine said the harsh measures had succeeded in stopping spread to other regions.But he added: “The concern is what will happen after they end these measures.”Elsewhere in the region, Singapore reported  new cases, of which  were imported.Japan also reported three new cases on Wednesday as the worst-affected Hokkaido region, with  cases, eased its state of emergency for the first time since late February.The reappearance of the bug came despite claims by Japanese officials that there had been no surge of infected patients that led to the collapse of the medical environment.South Korea saw a jump of  new cases yesterday with many of those believed to have been imported, centering on a nursing home in Daegu, where  patients tested positive.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPubs, shops, airports and train stations face enforced shutdowns and people can be fined £, for refusing a test in sweeping new coronavirus laws published today. Tory ministers plan to give themselves vast powers over almost every aspect of public le in order to curb the spread of the Covid- outbreak. The -page Coronavirus Bill - to be rushed through Parliament next week - also allows police to keep you in quarantine for at least a MONTH. It allows mentally ill people to be detained or dead people to be medically certied on the opinion of just one doctor. Sweeping powers will force supermarkets to disclose any problems in the food supply or be fined % of their turnover. And morgues could be expanded and inquests stripped back in order to deal with at least , anticipated deaths. On the plus side, a new volunteer leave will allow people to take unpaid time offthey want to help deal with the epidemic. And it will become easier for retired medics and medical students to join the frontline eventhey havenapost ticked every box of their qualications. The laws are separate to, and were planned long before, reports of a lockdown in London. Downing Street has insisted there is zero prospect of travel in and out of the capital being halted. However, they will allow authorities to enforce the advice not to travel or gather socially - and ensure the state doesnapost drown in paperwork rather than treating the sick. On the other hand, many MPs have raised concerns that the Bill is far too wide-ranging and hands the government too much executive power. Many of its measures can last two years without any extra approval by Parliament. Labour MP Chris Bryant said: I am not going to vote for draconian emergency measures that don’t have a renewal clause, preferably every thirty or sixty days. Two years is excessive for measures that restrict liberty and even six months is not good enough. I hope to table amendments later today. Human rights group Liberty warned the Bill has dramatic changes to civil liberties and greater surveillance could be ushered in through the backdoor - saying there must be tighter scrutiny. So whataposs in the emergency laws  Hereaposs everything you need to know. Police can force you to undergo treatment - or you could be arrested and fined £,. Andyouaposre infectious, police can keep you in quarantine for  DAYS  Police, immigration officers and public health officials will have the power to force someone to undergo a coronavirus test - and they can be fined £,they flee. Anyone deemed “potentially infectious” can be detained for up to  hours, or  hours by immigration officials, while they undergo a screening for the disease. Anyone “reasonably suspected” to have the virus, or to have been in an infected area in the last  days, can be held. They must be informed of their rights but it will be a criminal offence to refuse or to abscond. Public health officers can then exercise further powersthey believe they are “necessary and proportionate” to stop the person infecting others. This can include forcing people to remain in isolation, and restrictions on travel, activities and contact with other people. The Bill gives public health officials the power to force someone into isolation for up to  days. If a public health officer believes the person will be potentially infectious at the end of the period, it can be extended by up to a further  days -  in total. Once an extension has happened, the forced isolation must be reviewed at least every  hours andthe person is no longer infectious they can be released. The quarantine can be enforced by police - who can take anyone who absconds into custody and then forciblythem into quarantine. Overall, these powers exist for as long as ministers have declared there is a “serious and imminent threat to public health” from COVID-. Thereaposll be a new aposemergency volunteer leaveapos for ordinary heroes to help out  The government is introducing new emergency volunteer leaveapos to allow Brits who want to help the fight against coronavirus to do their bit. They hope the new scheme will increase the numbers of volunteers and free up the essential workers in the health service, social care and other vital services. It is unpaid leave, but enforced by law, and there will be funding to compensate those helping for some of their loss of earnings and expenses. The government says the new measure would help remove two of the main obstacles to people volunteering - namely time of work and the need to earn money.  The Bill gives government ministers wide-ranging powers to cancel events and gatherings at their orders in a few circumstances. They have to believe it is either an event which they feel will encourage the spread of coronavirus - or that it will be a drain on the medical resources. It will mean they can instruct authorities to stop people from entering premises, or impose restrictions on people who own or are organising an event to force them to cancel events. It also gives ministers the power to close “events or gatherings of a specied description” meaning they could close bars, restaurants or any other type of specied venue. The Secretary of State for Health will have to make a public declaration of any restriction in writing - and the Chief Medical Officer, or their deputy, will have a role in the process as well. Port, airports and railway stations can be temporarily shut  Ministers will be given the power to order ports, airports or international rail terminals to suspend activitiesthey can show that there is a risk of Covid- spreading or the Border Force is unable to adequately control the border because of pressures where. The Bill says the power can only be usedthere is a signicant risk to the public. The initial suspension can last no longer than six hours. It can be extended by notice for  hours and then at  hour intervalsnotice is given - but each time the government must demonstrate that the situation is dangerousthe port is not closed. Supermarkets will be forced to co-operate with government over panic-buying  The Bill gives the government sweeping powers to force privately-run supermarkets to disclose any disruption is to the food supply. The Environment Secretary will be able to “require information from persons within, or closely connected to, a food supply chain”he believes it is at risk of disruption. Such information can’t be demanded from an inidual - protecting inidual farmers and corner shop owners - but it can be used against food producers, slaughterhouses, packaging centres, distributors and retailers. Firms that refuse to comply can be fined % of their entire turnover, which for a major supermarket firm would be many millions of pounds. The idea is so the government has an overall picture of the food supply in the UK. Retired medics and medical students can be rushed in to treat patients  As part of the Bill, recently-retired doctors and medical students will be registered as regulated healthcare professionals more quickly and with fewer checks. This is to boost the number of NHS staff available to treat coronavirus patients. The Bill also makes it easier to bring NHS workers out of retirement. Currently, a former NHS worker’s pension benefits are suspendedtheyto work. The law will ensure they carry on getting their pension. Other parts of the Bill are similar and designed to remove bureaucracy on coming out of retirement. Royal College of Nursing Chief Executive and General Secretary Dame Donna Kinnair, said: Many nursing students and some recently retired nurses will want to play their part in helping to tackle the epidemic. We have been clear that students in the last six months of their degree must be free to choose to work. They must also be supported and supervised during their placements, and be properly remunerated. And aposbed blockingapos patients can be rushed out of hospital The bill will reduce the stages before a patient with social care needs can be discharged from hospital in order to speed up the process. This is because one of the biggest priorities is to maximise the number of hospital beds available. It will also change the way that councils have to provide social care by allowing them to prioritise the most serious cases. Checks on social workers can be relaxed Social workers who have recently left the profession will be temporarily added to registers to pick up any shortfalls in service. Suitably experienced people could also in temporarily registered as social workers ad the approval of the Registrar of Social Work in either England or Wales - this could include final year social work students. One doctor on their own will be allowed to detain a mentally ill person The Bill temporarily amends the Mental Health Act to allow fewer doctors’ opinions to be sought when detaining someone on mental health grounds. Currently, two doctoraposs opinions are required, it will be reduced to one for the two years from the date this Bill is passed. It also means that fewer doctors need to be consulted when it comes to detaining prisoners with mental health conditions against their will. There will be fewer checks before death certicates and cremations Doctors who haven’t actually seen the dead patient will be able to sign a death certicate under a relaxation in the law. Loved ones will also be able to register a death without visiting the Register Office in person. Meanwhile, authorities in England and Wales will be able to cremate a dead person based on a medical certicate from just one medical practitioner. The current law requires a second medical certicate confirming the details - a reform that was brought in to stop a repeat of mass murderer doctor Harold Shipman. The move “is aimed at simplying the process in order to address the expected increased volume of deaths”, and the need to keep doctors on the frontline, the government says.  Councils can build temporary morgues Councils could be given the power to step up planning to create temporary morgues - with the ability to make inquiries about finding places to hold bodiesnecessary. National authorities - once authorised by a minister - could require iniduals or companies to make available facilities that could help in the storage, disposal or transportation of dead bodies. Examples given are commandeering facilities at private funeral homes or crematoria. If a local authority is failing to perform these duties it gives the national government the power to step in and take over the handling of the deceased. In some cases, it also gives local authorities the power to direct whether a body is buried or cremated It also makes it easier for companies, local authorities and national governments to share information without falling foul of the law. Coronavirus inquests wonapost have juries Current law says Covid- is a “notiable disease” which means every death from it needs an inquest with a -person jury. This would have “signicant resource implications” as the government is planning on the basis of at least , deaths from the virus. So instead a coroner will be able to hold a simpler inquest without a jury in order to give families closure.  The NHS will be shielded from clinical negligence claims The Bill provides an “indemnity” from many clinical negligence claims against the NHS. This includes cases of people who have been treated for coronavirus, and “business as usual” activities that are disrupted or affected in some way by the outbreak. It is not immediately clearthis blocks legal action being brought altogether, or gives the NHS a defence and or covers its costs. We’ve asked for clarity. “Indemnity for such activities is not available where indemnity arrangements are already in place that cover the clinical negligence liability in question”, the government says. The government can force a school to shut, pupils to attend a dferent school, and pupil teacher ratios to change The bill gives the government a range of powers concerning education. It says that what is in the best interests of pupils and staff will “y according to the level of risk which presents itself in a particular place at a particular time”. It gives government the power to require or direct the temporary closure of a school, college or childcare provider. But it also gives the power to make “specied types of direction in connection with the running” of schools and other places. This might include keeping certain institutions open - or it could mean some pupils of key workers or who are vulnerable attend a dferent school to the one they normally do. Finally the bill gives the power to “dis-apply or y specied existing requirements” so this might include things like reducing the ratio of staff to children to account for staff absences but more clarity will be needed on this issue.

title: coronavirus isolation diary woke up
story: NewsopinionMy coronavirus isolation diary - I woke up feeling like Id smoked  cigarettes in an hourThe Mirrors political correspondent Mikey Smith describes his experience of self-isolation with suspected coronavirus - saying taking one step feels like too muchShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR NewsopinionMirrors political correspondent Mikey Smith is self-isolating at home with suspected coronavirus" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailItaposs Wednesday. The last couple of days I’ve woken up feeling like I’d smoked  cigarettes the night before. Yesterday I woke up feeling like I’d smoked  in the last hour. I had an occasional - but not continuous - cough, a headache and aches in my muscles. It was time to self-isolate. I’d already been working from home since Sunday and hadn’t really been out and about much since Friday. Our team started ‘social distancing’ at the end of last week, cutting down the number of staff physically in our office in the Houses of Parliament to the minimum to avoid unnecessary spreading. I’ve worked from home before, so I like to think I know a lot of the tricks. Get dressed. Don’t work in bed - have a desk set up, evenit’s the kitchen table. Have a set beginning and end to your work day. But I didn’t make it past step one yesterday. My partner is - so far - asymptomatic, but has entered isolation with me. We share an extremely small home - welcome to London - so she’s inevitably a couple of days behind me.  Both of us have made a point of not stockpiling. We’ve got enough - ahem - personal items to last a couple of weeks, but that’s about what we keep in anyway. The only things we’ve got more of than usual are ‘quality of le’ things, like a couple of bags of nice coffee beans. Little luxuries that make a couple of weeks stuck in the house feel less like a prison sentence.  Of course, in trying to do the right thing, we’ve ended up without a few things. Nothing dramatic - the biggest problem is that I don’t have a thermometer in the house, so I can’t tellI actually have a temperature. Not sure it matters at this point - my chest feeling like it’s being crushed under a rock is enough evidence for me - but it would have been nice. But a big shout out to the guys on Amazon offering £. thermometers for free delivery in a month’s time - or £you want it this week. Classy. Anyway, I’m settled in. I’m drinking lots of fluids, resting in bed and getting used to the four walls I’ll be looking at for the next week. Symptoms: Coughing, shortness of breath and chest tightness, headache, muscle pains. What’s entertaining me: Season  of Star Trek: Deep Space Nine on Netflix. story: NewsScottish politician Derek Mackay who messaged teenage boy will not be charged by policeMr Mackay resigned on the eve of the Scottish budget statement after the online conversations between him and the boy were revealedShareByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsDerek Mackay resigned just hours before he was due to deliver the Scottish budget " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailScotlandaposs former finance secretary Derek Mackay will not be charged over messages sent to a teenage boy that led to his resignation. Police Scotland has finished its investigation into the  messages sent by Mr Mackay via Instagram and Facebook to the -year-old boy and concluded no crime was committed. Mr Mackay resigned on the eve of the Scottish budget statement after the online conversations between him and the boy were published by the Scottish Sun. Messages from the Renfrewshire North and West MSP reportedly called the boy cute, invited him to events and asked their conversations be kept secret. A Police Scotland spokeswoman said: No reports of criminality has been made to Police Scotland. However, we have carried out inquiries and assessed all of the available information. Based on this, there is nothing to suggest that an offence has been committed. If anyone has any further information then they should contact Police Scotland on , or  in an emergency, The teenager was later reported as telling the Scottish Sun: I was happy to speak to the police and will tell them everything that happened.

title: coronavirus britains army volunteers helping
story: NewsCoronavirus: Britains army of volunteers helping those in need during the crisisAll across Britain, people are reaching out to link elderly or vulnerable residents with volunteers who can collect shopping and medication, post letters or even walk the dogShareCommentsByMaryam Qaiser:,  MAR NewsVounteers helping to deliver food in Nottingham " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailVolunteer Ellie Winfield gently places a carrier bag on the doorstep of a semi. It contains a few essentials, bread, chicken and cheese, but is the dference between peace of mind and worry for a family. Laura Ross, , is in hospital, suffering a neurological disorder, while her children Charlotte, , and Sam, , are stuck inside the family home in Beeston, Nottingham, self-isolating due to an underlying health issue. Now there is one less thing for them to worry about as a support group near their home has stepped in to help. Ellie, , of the Beeston and Chilwell Area Mutual Aid Group, is just one of an army of volunteers doing their bit to help in the crisis. As her kids Elliot, five, and Emelia, three, wait patiently, Ellie texts Charlotte to say the delivery is there. Then Ellie, who also volunteers at a food bank, tells me: “It is really important we care and look after our elderly and vulnerable members of the community.” For Laura, it has been a leline. Messaging from hospital, she says she had hoped an online shopping order would supply her children while she is in hospital.Laura says: “Charlotte is self-isolating as she has arthritis and is on immune suppressing drugs.“We hoped we would be fine as we managed to get an online delivery slot but a quarter of the shopping didn’t come. “Thankfully, a volunteer from the group was on hand to help my children. The group has been a godsend. To know there are amazing people out there helping my family while I’m in hospital means so much. “I am part of the group and I am trying to help with the admin, as I can’t physically help.” Residents across the UK have created support groups via Facebook and WhatsApp to link elderly or vulnerable residents with volunteers who can collect shopping and medication, post letters or even walk the dog.Paul Swt, , helped set up the Beeston and Chilwell group, which has more than , volunteers. When we meet up, Paul has a van of food and household items ready to be delivered to those in need. After heading to a local pub we co-ordinate the deliveries and make drop-off plans. A few elderly residents living alone approach Paul, who matches them with a volunteer living close-by. After Ellie drops off Laura’s groceries, we get smiles and nods of appreciation from other neighbours.  There is a real sense of community. Later, Paul is due to pick up medication for a mum, for her poorly son, but it is cancelled at the last minute. Paul explains the woman had found a relative to help. He says: “Plans are always changing at the last minute, because people’s circumstances can change.” But he says: “I have an uncle of  and an aunt of  with health problems. I wouldn’t like to think of them strugglingthey didn’t have me. Not everybody has relatives nearby. “We have been posting leaflets through doors so everyone knows we are here. This scheme shows just how much community spirit there is.” Many others are trying to help out. A local taxi firm, Nottingham-based DG Cars, is delivering free milk and bread to over-s and frontline NHS workers.

Gill Wood, , and her husband Colin are now in a race to get home after the Foreign Office announced advised all UK citizens must leave Spain by March .The couple were - who were visiting the island on a two-week package holiday -  were due tohome on Sunday, after a two-week package holiday to the Spanish Island, Manchester Evening News reports.The couple from  Didsbury, say they have been given no information from the airline about whether another flight will be available.The Foreign Office has advised that all UK citizens must leave Spain by Tuesday, March . story: NewsCoronavirus: Customers in tears over soaring paracetamol prices and £ CalpolAnxious shoppers called Birmingham City councillor Majid Mahmood to complain the price hikes - who slammed them for "charging extortionate pricing" when "people are desperate in a national crisis"ShareCommentsByRichard Vernalls:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe childrens medicine was being sold at a hugely inflated price " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. The Birmingham pharmacy came has come under fire after bottles of ml liquid paracetamol appeared for sale at one branch for about treble the average standard price. City councillor Majid Mahmood said he had five people from his ward tearfully ringing him up about the rises on Wednesday. His Bromford and Hodge Hill ward sits in one of the most deprived constituencies in England, with a  study commissioned by the End Child Poverty Coalition finding more than half of children grew up in poverty.Mr Mahmood posted a photograph on Twitter, taken in the pharmacy, showing the price of ml of Calpol as £. and a ml bottle listed for £..At other online retailers - where Calpol has sold out - prices were listed at around £. and £., respectively. Mr Mahmood added that at the same store, a -pack of paracetamol pills which had been £. last week had risen to £.. Jhoots, which runs the site, said in a statement that disparities in some branches had stemmed from an erroneous communication and it had since taken steps to correct prices. The business, based in Walsall in the West Midlands, said it would also refund any affected customers and ensure no repeat of the error. It comes as the pharmacy industry has been warning of how wholesale paracetamol prices have gone up in the current climate, due to supplier issues. Commenting on the rise at his local pharmacy, Mr Mahmood said: Business is business, they have to make a profit. But firms shouldnapost be charging extortionate pricing when you know people are desperate in a national crisis.  When youaposve got people crying down the phone because they canapost afford Calpol - thataposs wrong. He added: Jhoots have said it was an erroneous communication to some branches but the fact is theyaposve got a social responsibility as a pharmacy. In a statement posted on Twitter responding to social media criticism of the pricing, Jhoots said: It has been brought to our attention that pricing disparities occurred yesterday at a small number of our branches. We have acted immediately and conducted a thorough investigation into this matter and have found that following an erroneous communication, price increases were made at branch level.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWith so much new advice and the ever-changing situation with coronavirus, it can be very confusing. Here, Dr Miriam Stoppard answers your questions on everything from self-isolating to risk groups and future plans... We are told deaths relating to coronavirus are people with underlying health problems. Can you clary what these might be  Brenda Tiley, , from Luton Underlying health problems mean any chronic medical condition such as heart disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, lung disease, kidney disease and liver disease. Cancer and cancer treatments like chemotherapy would also make a person vulnerable. These conditions put a strain on the immune system and make the body less resilient, so you should follow all the advice the Government has given us – e.g. self-isolating, not mixing with people, not going out and not travelling.I’m  and have had three heart attacks but feel healthy, should I self-isolate  I also had Asian flu in , will I still have the antibodies from this and will they protect me against Covid-  Frank Robinson, Swinton, Manchester Despite feeling healthy, your three heart attacks put you in the vulnerable group, so you should self-isolate. I wish I could say having Asian flu in  would protect you but I’m afraid it won’t. Each virus is specic and the only thing that would protect us is a specic vaccination for Covid-. My daughter and daughter-in-law are pregnant. Both are going to work from home but are pregnant women more at risk from this virus and are there any precautions they should be taking  Tina Wallman, , Camberley, Surrey Pregnant women are always considered a special group that requires special attention. In this outbreak, that doesn’t change. In fact, the Chief Medical Officer has put pregnant women into the “vulnerable” group, alongside older people and those that have underlying medical conditions. Soyour daughter and daughter-in-law can, I suggest they self-isolate, stay in their homes, do not mix with other people and do not go outdoors unless necessary.  I’m  with underlying health conditions and I play golf regularly. Should I carry on while avoiding physical contact with playing partners, and avoiding the bar and clubhouse  I enjoy the fresh air and exercise. Peter Sidebotham, Stalybridge, Cheshire It’s great that you play golf to keep fit butyou have underlying health conditions I wouldn’t advise you continue to play – there will always be mixing with other people and you’d be exposed to contaminated surfaces. If there’s any way you could play entirely on your own, without any contact with others, it might work. If this isn’t possible you should stop playing golf altogether for the time being. Those experiencing coronavirus symptoms, such as a cough or fever, should self-isolate for  days.You should stay at homeyou or or anyone in your household has a high temperature or a new and continuous cough - evenitaposs mild. Everyone in your household must stay at home for  days and keep away from others DO NOT go to your GP or hospital.Go to NHS.UK to check your symptoms and follow the specialist medical advice.Only call you canapost get online, you feel like you canapost cope at home, or your symptoms do not get better after the seven days. If you are pregnant you should call you have any concerns about yourself or unborn baby during self-isolation. Pregnant women are advised to contact their midwe, out-of-hours helplines or a maternity team who will provide information on whether you need to go to hospital.  I have mental health disorders including depression, as well as underlying physical health conditions. I’m worried I’ll become more depressed, anxious and vulnerableI self-isolate. Should I stop going out because of coronavirus already, and what can I doI do to help my mental health  Name withheld I’m very sympathetic but with your medical background you’d be well advised to self-isolate and put in place some things that could protect you from loneliness. First, I think you should make a resolution to Skype family or friends at least once a day. Phoning a friend a couple of times each day would help as well. Be more active on social media s and engage with your online friends. Make sure you’re eating a healthy diet, not too much coffee, no alcohol – and get a good night’s sleep.  Is delaying the spread the best policy  Won’t it just prolong people’s anxiety  Ian Mussett Delaying the spread is the strategy to take pressure off the NHS. There are downsides and you describe one of them. I don’t think anyone will relax until we hit a peak of some sort. As it happens, it might not be possible to delay the spread. The Government may have acted too late with restrictive measures. To my mind, we should be going further, as they are in France and Spain, with almost total lockdown. It worked in Wuhan and South Korea. Why aren’t we doing it  I’m  with type  diabetes and on insulin. I’ve had an aorta valve change and I’m on blood thinners. I have high blood pressure too. I’m due to look after my granddaughterher school closes but would that be wise  Alan Bebb, Runcorn, Cheshire With all your medical complaints, you’re vulnerable. I think you should be self-isolating, only going out to shop for food or get your medication. I don’t think it is a good idea to look after your granddaughter, she’ll probably be OK but she might carry the virus to you. The latest advice is not to even meet up with your family. My we and I are in our s and she has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. We have a holiday booked for June . I have paid a deposit and need to pay the balance in April to keep the holiday. Should I  Graham Newnes, Rutland The NHS has stopped advising coronavirus patients to take ibuprofen amid concerns the anti-inflammatory painkiller could only make things worse. A statement read: There is currently no strong evidence that ibuprofen can make coronavirusworse. But until we have more information, take paracetamol to treat the symptoms of coronavirus, unless your doctor has told you paracetamol is not suitable for you. If you are already taking ibuprofen or another non-steroidal anti-inflammatoryon the advice of a doctor, do not stop taking it without checking first. I don’t think so. The Government’s guidelines say because of your age, you and your we fall into the vulnerable category – especially as she suffers from COPD. This means you should self-isolate, not travel and not mix with other people, like eating out in cafés and restaurants. It’s a shame but I think you’ll have to lose your deposit. I’m  and my we is  and she is susceptible to pneumonia. We’ve recently moved and don’t have any friends or relatives close by. In the case of self-isolating, we’ll have no one to help. What should we do  Roger Baber, Bideford, Devon You could stay in touch by phone, Skype, WhatsApp and social media. By doing this you speak to someone every day. You can also keep your family and friends alert to feeling unwell and they can help you get support. You or your family could phone the local council to seethere’s a service that would do your shopping. I know it’s hard because a lot of us are going to feel bereft in the coming months but we just have to do what we can. What’s the best way to help your immune system cope with the virus  Ray Baguely, , Newport There’s nothing you can do from the outside to boost your immune system. The only way would be to have a vaccination so your immune system produced antibodies specically against coronavirus. Exposure to the virus could stimulate your immune system to produce those antibodies itself.  With over-s spending more time at home, will those without access to a garden be advised to take vitamin D  Linda Rachel, , Ipswich With so little sunshine during the winter, people in the older age group are already advised to take mcg of vitamin D every day in the autumn and winter months. For people confined to their homes it’s even more important to follow this advice. My daughter is in her s and expecting her first baby mid-May. She is terried of there not being a bed available when she goes into labour. How can I reassure her on this  Wendy from Cardf

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn elderly gentleman was pictured staring at his shopping list in an aisle with bare shelves after panic-buyers defied instructions to stockpile their shopping. The poignant image shows the man looking down at a shopping list in front of bare shelves in his local store in Epsom, Surrey. Other shocking images of pensioners looking for food in supermarkets with limited supplies have also circulated on social media. Lauren Taylor, , who took the photo of the gentleman, said she hoped the picture would kick the public into action to take care of the elderly. The mum-of-two explained that multiple aisles on the supermarket had limited supply. She said: It was awful and just really sad. That was only one aisle and the others were in a similar state of empty shelves. People were grabbing lots of the stuff that were still on the shelves. Itaposs really just sad and disappointing in society that itaposs got to this point. Everyone needs stuff, but he had been left with nothing. Supermarket giants have moved to limit the number of crucial items people can buy. Tesco said shoppers will be limited to buying just three products per line from Thursday. Chief executive Dave Lewis added all counter services will close, to free up staff to restock shelves, and a priority hour will be launched at larger stores between am and am every Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Stores that previously opened  hours, will also now close at pm each evening.  The move follows similar measures by Sainsburyaposs, Aldi, Asda and Morrisons, to ease stockpiling pressure amid the Covid- outbreak. Sainsburyaposs revealed it will only allow customers to buy a maximum of three of any single item, while Morrisons said it is limiting purchases across , lines. Asda also announced it is restricting shoppers to three items on all food and closing its cafés and pizza counters, while temporarily reducing the opening hours of all its -hour stores for re-stocking. Aldi has already introduced limits of four items per shopper across all products.  Tesco boss Mr Lewis wrote to staff on Wednesday: It is fair to say that we find ourselves in uncharted waters. Covid- is bringing a change to the UK and itaposs clear that lots of things are going to have to sht around in order to help us cope.At Tesco, we have been doing everything we can to keep business as usual, but we now have to accept it is not business as usual. In the last two weeks, we have seen signicant and prolonged increases in demand across all of our stores and this is leading to shortages in some products for some customers. It comes as Britainaposs supermarket chains are also launching action to help elderly and vulnerable customers, while ramping up operations to meet surging demand for home deliveries.  Sainsburyaposs became the latest group to offer priority home delivery slots to elderly and vulnerable customers, as well as exclusive shopping hours. Its supermarkets will only open to these two groups for the first hour of trading on Thursday, chief executive Mike Coupe said, but will open for an hour longer so other shoppers do not miss out. Sainsburyaposs Local convenience stores will not offer the service. Supermarkets have seen a huge rise in demand for delivery services, with no slots available until next month for both Tesco and Waitrose in some parts of the south east. The surge came as Transport Secretary Grant Shapps authorised a temporary relaxation, until April , of the driversapos hours rules to help deliver goods to stores across the country. The government has advised the British public to:Avoid pubs, clubs, restaurants and all social gatherings Cease all unnecessary travel Everyone should work from home where possible Mass gatherings and sporting events have been cancelled Avoid “all but essential travel” worldwide If one person in any household has a persistent cough or fever, everyone living there must stay at home for  days Pregnant women, those over , and people with certain health conditions have been asked to stay at home for  weeks Schools, colleges and nurseries to close from Friday - GCSEs and A-levels cancelled A Department for Transport statement said the relaxation applies only to drivers supplying food and essential products to supermarkets. The statement added: This includes the movement of such goods from importers, manufactures and suppliers to distribution centres. It does not apply to drivers undertaking deliveries directly to consumers. Iceland outlets across the country have also introduced reserved time slots to give the vulnerable and the elderly a chance to shop in store. Sainsburyaposs said customers over  and those with a disability will have priority access to online delivery slots from Monday, and the chain is also expanding its click and collect service.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Queen has asked people in the UK to come together to protect our most vulnerable as the country battles against coronavirus COVID-. The monarch shared a message of solidarity shortly after she arrived at Windsor Castle with Prince Philip this afternoon. Speaking about the dficulties ahead, as millions of people prepare to stay at home rather than going about their normal day-to-day lives, she said: I am certain we are up to that challenge.The Monarchaposs statement follows similar messages from Prince William, Meghan Markle and Prince Harry.In her message, the Queen asked Brits to do a number of things during this dficult time. To change our day-to-day routines The Queen urges people to follow government guidelines to try to stop the spread. People have been asked to refrain socialising and to only travelitaposs completely necessary. Anyone who can should work from home and schools will close next week. While inconvenient, experts have said itaposs vital to save lives of those in the aposat riskapos groups.  She said: We are all being advised to change our normal routines and regular patterns of le for the greater good of the communities we live in and, in particular, to protect the most vulnerable within them. To work together She has also asked people to come together in their communities. She said: At times such as these, I am reminded that our nation’s history has been forged by people and communities coming together to work as one, concentrating our combined efforts with a focus on the common goal.  To support our emergency services and vital workers While the majority of us are being asked to work from home, those that work in vital jobs still have to go in. This means theyaposre risking catching the virus and getting ill in order to help the rest of us carry on.  Doctors, nurses, delivery drivers, supermarket staff and other people are being widely praised, and the Queen has also urged us to support them. She said: We are enormously thankful for the expertise and commitment of our scientists, medical practitioners and emergency and public services but now more than any time in our recent past, we all have a vitally important part to play as iniduals - today and in the coming days, weeks and months. To look out for our loved ones The Queenaposs final message is perhaps her most powerful. She asked people to reach out to their loved ones to ensure they are well and safe.

He added further guidance about how to do this will be published on Friday and talks with school leaders are still ongoing. The Education Secretary said there will have to be an appeals process for any pupil who feels theyaposve been wronged. The Mirror understands it is possible universities could use predicted grades,they resume as normal in September, but this is not confirmed. But what will the schools closure mean for children, parents and families Here is everything we know so far, as reported by Bristol Live.  What schools are involved  The Prime Minister made it clear that all schools would be involved in the shutdown across England, following announcements in Scotland and Wales. Mr Johnson also said that he would be aposexpectingapos childrenaposs nurseries, pre-schools, sixth-forms and colleges to also close their doors.  How long will the shutdown be for  The Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said that schools will shut their gates at the end of Friday and then be shut indefinitely - the Government are careful not to put a time frame or date on when they may reopen. When asked by journalists at the Number  briefing that happened simultaneously, Mr Johnson appeared to rebuff the suggestion, made in Wales and Ireland, that the school closures could be for as long as six months - that Friday would effectively mark the end of the school year, and the summer term after Easter would simply not happen, with schools reopening in September. He said he would hope that schools could reopen before then, but with the coronavirus pandemic rapidly spreading throughout Britain, there is no certainty at all on when they would reopen.  Who will still go to school  The Education Secretary said that schools would remain open for the children of keyworkers, to ensure that people who the country needs to continue to go to work and not worry about childcare, will be able to do so. The Prime Minister said these would be the children of NHS workers, police and emergency services personnel and aposdelivery driversapos who are critical to ensuring the continuing working of the food supply from farm to factory to shops. The Prime Minister said exactly who would be in this list would be revealed this week, before Friday - but there are no firm details as yet, on Wednesday evening.   What about grandparents  There was a specic warning from the Prime Minister that, under no circumstances, children should be now looked after by their grandparents, once they are home from school. That generation of older people are the most vulnerable to coronavirus, and the message from the scientists is that young people and the elderly should be kept apart to avoid older people catching the virus.  What should parents do  One of the key reasons why schools are now being closed is to further ensure that a partial lockdown of society happens. Parents are being asked to look after their children at home, and not leave them with grandparents, and this move is designed to increase the numbers of people who largely withdraw and remain in their homes, to stop the further spread.Most controversially, however, Boris Johnson again held back from making lockdowns and closures of businesses an order - even though all other countries in Europe are pursuing those more severe measures.  What about exams  The Prime Minister confirmed that, given schools will be closed for a considerable time and exams start in May, this yearaposs  GCSEs and A-levels would be scrapped. This does mean that exams will not take place in May and June as planned, but we will make sure that students get the exams they need and deserve, said Mr Johnson. Quite how that happens is unclear, but the most likely explanation will be some kind of grade awarded from coursework already completed, or predictive grades or grades from mock exams.  What about vulnerable children  School children who are classed as vulnerable will be still be allowed to go to school - this includes children who have an EHCP - children with special needs - and children who have a social worker or are in care.  What about Free School Meals  The Prime Minister outlined that they would be rapidly drawing up plans for a voucher scheme for children who are entitled to free school meals - but who will now not be at school to receive it each day - to get that food or support. The details of how exactly this works are yet to be revealed.

In a heartbreaking video, Dawn Bilbrough, , from York, asks people to just stop taking more food than needed, warning the public itaposs key workers who will be looking after you when youaposre at your lowest. She admits she had a little cry in the supermarket after seeing the fruit and vegetable shelves totally bare. I donapost know how Iaposm supposed to stay healthy. And those people... people are  just stripping the shelves of basic foods. You just need to stop it. Because itaposs people like me that are going to be looking after you when youaposre at your lowest so just stop it. Please! The video comes as supermarkets bring in more stringent measures to ensure food is distributed more evenly among society. Shelves have been stripped bare at Tesco, Sainsburyaposs, Asda and Morrisons, as customers attempt to purchase essential items such as toilet roll, handwash and pasta. There were also violent scenes at an Iceland store in Ilford, east London, earlier this week after an elderly shopper was pushed and shoved out of a packed Iceland store. Customers were seen queuing outside an Aldi even before the doors opened this morning, with most people heading to the loo rolls section straight away - even though the Government has told Britons not to panic buy. Major supermarkets including Sainsburyaposs, Tesco, Aldi and Morrisons have rationed how much of certain products customers can buy. Some have restricted purchases in-demand items like toilet roll, paracetemol and pasta, while others have brought in blanket bans on multiple purchases. Itaposs just one of a number of measures brought in by the nationaposs grocers, as pictures of empty shelves spread through social media like wildfire. Panic buyers have stripped shelves of everything they can - in some cases leaving just ice cream and chocolate Easter eggs - while huge queues snaked around some supermarkets ahead of opening on Wednesday. Currently there are no official limits coming down from the Government, although pressure is growing to impose them, and supermarket bosses insist there is no shortage - simply people over-buying.  In the interim, the shops have taken action themselves - limiting customer purchases and opening hours. Competition laws will be temporarily relaxed to allow supermarkets to collaborate in feeding the nation during the coronavirus crisis. Retailers will be able to pool staff, share data on stock levels, and share distribution depots and delivery vans as the Government seeks to ease restrictions under the exceptional circumstances. The temporary relaxation only permits retailers to work together for the sole purpose of feeding the nation as they face a strain from intense demand amid panic buying, ministers said. The p plastic bag charge will also be waived for online purchases to hasten deliveries, and driversapos hours will be relaxed so more food can be delivered to stores.

Marilyn Lundy, , says she had to leave Sainsbury’s empty-handed last week after she found the shelves stripped bare because of coronavirus panic-buying. The pensioner, from Urmston in Greater Manchester, says the experience left her feeling extremely fearful. Speaking to the Manchester Evening News, Mrs Lundy explained how she and her -year-old husband, who suffers from heart problems and diabetes, have been trying to self-isolate since last week to protect themselves from COVID-. The couple normally get an online shop delivered every Tuesday, but this week only half the order arrived. Unable to book another slot until April  - two weeks away - she decided to risk leaving the house and head to the shops, only to find that other shoppers had bought up essential items. With my age and my husbandaposs health, we decided to self-isolate a week ago, Marilyn said. I thought that it wouldnapost be too dficult to do as I have been getting my shopping online for years. I will usually get a whole weekaposs shop and then I might pop into the supermarket to get the odd thing. My order arrived on Tuesday and only about half or the order actually came, so I thought okay, Iaposll just make another. These people who have emptied the shelves are now online getting what they need and I find it very wrong.”  Marilyn says she is going to try and get to Sainsburyaposs for the dedicated elderly shopping hour at am, but fears she will miss out again. She says she is also worried of increasing the risk to her husband every time she steps food inside a supermarket. Where do I go from here ” she added. I tried to call Sainsburyaposs but there was no answer, I sent an email but havenapost had a reply. It just feels like people like me donapost matter. The pensioner hit out at those who have been stockpiling unnecessarily - and says supermarkets should be doing more to stop it. They havenapost done enough to stop people stockpiling, Marilyn said.  The other day I saw one couple with as much as they could get in their trolley, and once they had loaded their car, they went back into the shop to buy more. I think itaposs disgusting, I feel very hurt by it. Not everyone can shop online either. Not a lot of people my age do it and certainly not many people over the age of . People are going to the shop and there is just nothing there for them. Marilyn says she has been overwhelmed by offers of help from people on social media and local neighbours, but is keen to keep her independence. I will say that for all the greedy people out there now, there are just as many really nice people out there who have offered help, she added. But how can you ask someone who works to do a whole week shop for you. I am not so proud that I wonapost ask for help when I need it but I canapost give someone a whole week shopping list. Iaposve been independent until now and that is now being taken away from me.  Earlier this week Sainsbury’s announced it would introduce rationing in a drastic bid to limit panic-buying.
